newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Tajik peace talks stall over military plans.
newsitem.headline: Tajik peace talks stall over military plans.

text.p: Talks between the Tajik government and its Islamist opponents have stalled over plans to integrate armed opposition units into the military structure, Interfax news agency said on Saturday.
The Moscow talks are trying to work out military arrangements to support a U.N.-sponsored peace accord signed last December after four years of fierce civil war in the former Soviet republic.
Chief opposition negotiator Akbar Turazhonzoda told Interfax his side wanted its fighters to retain their battalion and company divisions within Tajikistan's armed forces.
The Moscow-backed government of President Imomali Rakhmonov, fearing the effective creation of an army within an army, wants the incorporated units to comprise only five to 10 men.
Russia, which has a large military force in the remote Central Asian republic of 5.7 million people, is mediating in the talks, which began last Wednesday.
A ceasefire has largely held since the December accord but Western observers say the two sides' inability to control armed bands who roam the mountainous state may jeopardise peace efforts.

Diplomats also say a power-sharing deal struck in Iran, sharing seats on a new commission for national reconciliation between the government and opposition, could be explosive because it left no places for any other faction.
It was not clear how long the talks in Moscow would last.
